terpene_database_schema.description: Comprehensive Cannabis Terpene Database with harmonized isomer notation, clinical plausibility validation, and tiered categorization.

categorization_tiers.Core: High-prevalence, clinically and chemically well-defined terpenes observed consistently across multiple cultivars. Examples: Beta-Myrcene, Beta-Caryophyllene, D-Limonene, Linalool, Alpha- & Beta-Pinene, Alpha-Humulene, Terpinolene.
categorization_tiers.Secondary: Terpenes with moderate prevalence, contributing to aroma or therapeutic nuance, but less consistently dominant. Examples: Nerolidol, Alpha-Bisabolol, Eucalyptol, Borneol, Caryophyllene Oxide, Delta-3-Carene, Ocimene, Geraniol.
categorization_tiers.Minor: Low-prevalence or emerging terpenes with limited cannabis-specific data or primarily known from external botanical evidence. Examples: Beta-Elemene, Bergamotene, Cedrene, Fenchone, Geranyl Acetate, Valencene, Farnesene.

schema_fields.name: Primary terpene name including optical or structural designation (e.g., 'D-Limonene', 'Alpha-Bisabolol')
schema_fields.isomerOf: If the compound is an isomer variant, specify its parent compound ('Limonene'); null if not applicable.
schema_fields.isomerType: Type of isomerism – 'Optical', 'Positional', 'Structural', or null if not relevant.
schema_fields.aroma: Comma-separated sensory descriptors (e.g., 'Citrus, sweet, pine, spicy').
schema_fields.taste: Flavor descriptors relevant to cultivar taste expression.
schema_fields.description: Literature-based terpene summary including key pharmacological and aromachemical roles.
effects: List of empirically supported primary physiological or psychoactive effects (e.g., 'Sedative', 'Anti-stress', 'Anxiolytic'). Each effect must be clinically plausible based on validated evidence.
therapeuticProperties: List of recognized therapeutic pharmacological actions (e.g., 'Anti-inflammatory', 'Neuroprotective', 'Analgesic').
schema_fields.notableDifferences: summarized differences supported by data: e.g., 'Only known CB2 agonist among terpenes', or 'D-form uplifting vs L-form mildly sedating.'
schema_fields.concentrationRange: Typical concentration range in cannabis dry flower, expressed in mg/g or normalized %. If not available, 'trace-minor' or null.

molecularData.molecularWeight: Molecular weight in atomic mass units (g/mol).
molecularData.boilingPoint: Boiling point in degrees Celsius; null if not applicable.

references.type: Peer-reviewed study, industry lab report, or botanical data

researchTier.dataQuality: Excellent, Good, Moderate, or Limited (based on evidence)
researchTier.evidenceSummary: Short statement summarizing dataset scope and quality (e.g., 'Observed in >95% cannabis cultivars with multiple GC-MS validations').

implementation_guidelines.isomer_handling: Maintain unique entries only for distinct chemotaxonomic or pharmacologically relevant isomers. Apparent aromatic variants without distinct biological profiles remain merged.
implementation_guidelines.effect_validation: All terpene effects will trace to validated cannabinoid-terpene synergy research (entourage effect, in vitro, or in vivo evidence as of Q3 2025). Unsupported claims are marked 'Unconfirmed'.
implementation_guidelines.update_policy: Semi-annual evidence review and harmonization of concentration ranges, supported by newly published GC-MS cannabis terpene profiling data.

example_entry.name: D-Limonene
example_entry.description: Citrus terpene responsible for uplifting and anti-stress properties; D-isomer found abundantly in citrus-scented cultivars.
example_entry.notableDifferences: D-form boosts serotonin; L-form mildly sedating; synergy observed with Beta-Caryophyllene in anxiolytic pathways.

researchTier.evidenceSummary: Confirmed across multiple chemovars with therapeutic validation.
